thread.title: Girl hailed for bravery after rescuing siblings from crash
thread.title_full: Girl hailed for bravery after rescuing siblings from crash

author: RACHEL CLUN
title: Girl hailed for bravery after rescuing siblings from crash
text:
Girl hailed for bravery after rescuing siblings from crash RACHEL CLUN Last updated 23:00, February 7 2017 SUPPLIED 
Lacey and Brenton Bradford pictured with their four children. 
A five-year-old girl rescued her three younger siblings from a car crash which killed their mother in Australia. 
Lacey Bradford's car rolled on a gravel road in central Queensland, leaving her fatally injured. 
Showing "true courage" in the face of the tragedy, her eldest daughter unclipped her four year old sister and the two-year-old twins from their seats and got them out of the car. 
The children then began the long walk home, before emergency services arrived and took them to hospital with minor injuries. 
The young mother had been driving her eldest children to meet the school bus when she crashed about 150 kilometres west of Rockhampton. 
Bradford had suffered severe head injuries, and was pronounced dead at the scene. 
Detective Sergeant Paul James, officer in charge of Duaringa Police Station, said the five-year-old girl had showed true courage. 
"She was definitely mature beyond her years, her act of bravery should be recognised," he said. 
A GoFundMe campaign has been set up to raise funds for Bradford's husband Brenton and their four young children. 
The campaign, set up by Mr Bradford's brother Lance, has raised more than $51,000 of the $60,000 goal in less than three days. Ad Feedback 
"The Bradford family have a long road ahead of them," Lance Bradford wrote on the campaign page. 
"Brenton is left with little idea on life ahead financially as his current living and working arrangements is an impossible task for a single father of four children given his remote location and job requirements." 
The funds raised will go towards funeral costs, bills, a new car, and care for the four children. - Brisbane Times
